item.title: Anonymous test data with AutoFixture
item.description: Often times we have unit or integration tests that rely on some input data. The easiest solution is just to take some hard-coded values and move on with life. This has some major downsides: Giving specific values in a test carries meaning, but we are often times not interested in that. We just need to pass the object around to fulfill the API. Also the simplest solution to fulfill your test is literally checking against those values. Here is an elegant solution to that problem: AutoFixture. I will show you what it can do, especially in combination with xUnit.

item.title: State monads in OCaml
item.description: Previously I talked about monads, which are just a way to create a "container" type (that contains some value), and let people chain computation within that container. It seems to be a pattern that's mostly useful in functional languages as they are often limited in the ways they can do things. Little did I know, there's more to monads, or at least monads are so vague that they can be used in all ...
item.author: (david wong)

item.title: Visual Studio 'Port Forwarding' Now 'Dev Tunnels,' So What's a Dev Tunnel? -- Visual Studio Magazine
item.description: A private preview of Visual Studio port forwarding in ASP.NET Core web-dev projects has turned into a public preview of dev tunnels, Microsoft announced this week. So what's a dev tunnel?
item.author: (By David Ramel11/18/2022)
